author: Staff reporters
title: Mark Latham's exit as Financial Review columnist sparks debate
text:
Mark Latham has controversially covered social issues including sharp critiques of feminism, the medicalisation of mental illness and anti-domestic violence campaigns. by Staff reporters The resignation of former Labor leader Mark Latham as a columnist with The Australian Financial Review has sparked controversy over the robustness of public debate.
The former federal opposition leader, who has been a columnist with the Financial Review and AFR Weekend for eight years, told editor-in-chief Michael Stutchbury on Sunday that he had written his last column for the masthead.
Mr Stutchbury said reports that Mr Latham had been dismissed by the Financial Review were wrong.
"Mark has been a provocative and highly readable columnist for the Financial Review ," Mr Stutchbury said. "He has been both loved and hated by readers â€“ sometimes by the same ones at different times. While I didn't agree with everything Mark wrote, he has played a significant role in Australian public life and brought rare personal insight into his writing."
Last week's AFR BOSS cover featuring from left: Mike Baird NSW Premier, Rosie Batty Australian of the Year and Catherine Livingstone head of the Business Council of Australia. Nic Walker After losing to John Howard in 2004, Mr Latham began what became a regular Financial Review column in the lead-up to the 2007 election.
More recently, he strongly defended former prime minister Julia Gillard over her relationship with the Australian Workers' Union in the 1980s that ended up being probed by the current Royal Commission into Trade Union Governance and Corruption.
Mr Latham also has controversially covered social issues from a self-styled western Sydney perspective, including sharp critiques of feminism, the medicalisation of mental illness and anti-domestic violence campaigns. He even criticised the past two Australians of the Year, Rosie Batty and Adam Goodes.
Legal action by Lisa Pryor Fellow Financial Review columnist and Institute of Public Affairs executive director John Roskam on Monday said Mr Latham's resignation suggested the public debate had gone "beyond creeping political correctness to outright authoritarianism". Matthew Piper Former columnist with The Sydney Morning Herald's Good Weekend magazine, Lisa Pryor has taken legal action against a Financial Review column Mr Latham wrote about her last year.
Feminist websites and activists have campaigned against Mr Latham's columns, including by complaining to Westpac, which presents the successful Women of Influence awards with the Financial Review .
Mr Stutchbury accepted there was always a line that responsible publications must not cross.
But he defended the Financial Review's right, and even duty, to publish provocative opinions that some might find offensive, as this was a hallmark of a vibrant democracy. No person or idea should be out of bounds for criticism because that would prevent them from being properly tested by the marketplace of free speech, he said.
In June, a Latham column scolded Ms Batty, who has become a campaigner against domestic violence after her 11-year-old son was murdered by his disturbed father.
It criticised her talking about her personal tragedy on the paid speaking circuit and accused left-wing feminism of depicting domestic violence as the result of a patriarchal gender power imbalance rather than a function of social disadvantage.
'Serious issue of public importance' Mr Stutchbury said the Financial Review's editors carefully considered this column before publishing but judged that Mr Latham had raised a serious issue of public importance.
The masthead gave generous scope for others to respond to Mr Latham's critique. And, on Friday last week, Ms Batty was pictured on the front of the inserted BOSS magazine as one of the magazine's 2015 "true leaders", chosen by an independent panel of judges. A Financial Review editorial praised her leadership contribution.
Asked about Mr Latham's columns last month, Sex Discrimination Commissioner Elizabeth Broderick indicated that she had been asked by women whether they should avoid the awards because of the association with the Financial Review .
Ms Broderick, who is the overall winner of this year's awards, said she supported free speech but suggested that Mr Latham's columns were damaging the Financial Review's brand.
Fellow Financial Review columnist and Institute of Public Affairs executive director John Roskam on Monday said Mr Latham's resignation suggested the public debate had gone "beyond creeping political correctness to outright authoritarianism.
"And that's a comment from someone who has only ever agreed with 30 per cent of anything Mark Latham has written," he said. "Mark has that special capacity to have you either violently agree or violently disagree with him."
